contents.description: It means the address at which you generally spend most time. For most people, this will be their permanent or family home.

Armed forces members, include yourself at your home address if you have one.

question.title: How is your health in general?

title.text: How is {person_name_possessive} health in general?

contents.description: This refers to health conditions, illnesses or impairments you may have.
Consider conditions that always affect you and those that flare up from time to time. These may include, for example, sensory conditions, developmental conditions or learning impairments.

definitions.title: What do we mean by “physical and mental health conditions or illnesses”?

question.title: Do you have any physical or mental health conditions or illnesses lasting or expected to last 12 months or more?

contents.description: This refers to health conditions, illnesses or impairments they may have.
Consider conditions that always affect them and those that flare up from time to time. These may include, for example, sensory conditions, developmental conditions or learning impairments.

definitions.title: What do we mean by “physical and mental health conditions or illnesses”?

title.text: Does {person_name} have any physical or mental health conditions or illnesses lasting or expected to last 12 months or more?

contents.description: We mean whether your health condition or illness currently affects your ability to carry out day-to-day activities.
Consider whether you are still affected while receiving any treatment, medication or using any devices for your condition or illness.
For example, if you need a hearing aid and by using the device you experience no restriction in carrying out your day-to-day activities, then you should select “Not at all”.
You should select “Yes, a lot” if you usually need some level of support from family members, friends or personal social services for most normal daily activities.

definitions.title: What do we mean by “reduce your ability”?

question.title: Do any of your conditions or illnesses reduce your ability to carry out day-to-day activities?

contents.description: We mean whether their health condition or illness currently affects their ability to carry out day-to-day activities.
Consider whether they are still affected while receiving any treatment, medication or using any devices for their condition or illness.
For example, if they need a hearing aid and by using the device they experience no restriction in carrying out their day-to-day activities, then you should select “Not at all”.
You should select “Yes, a lot” if they usually need some level of support from family members, friends or personal social services for most normal daily activities.

definitions.title: What do we mean by “reduce their ability”?

title.text: Does any of {person_name_possessive} conditions or illnesses reduce their ability to carry out day-to-day activities?

options.label: Yes, 9 hours a week or less
options.value: Yes, 9 hours a week or less

options.label: Yes, 50 or more hours a week
options.value: Yes, 50 or more hours a week

contents.description: Exclude anything you do as part of your paid employment

contents.description: We are measuring the number of people who have served in the UK Armed Forces and have now left. Government and councils need this information to carry out their commitments made under the Armed Forces Covenant. This is a promise by the nation ensuring that those who serve or who have served in the armed forces, and their families, are not disadvantaged.

options.label: Yes, previously served in Regular Armed Forces
options.value: Yes, previously served in Regular Armed Forces

options.label: Yes, previously served in Reserve Armed Forces
options.value: Yes, previously served in Reserve Armed Forces

contents.description: Current serving members should only select “No”

contents.description: To get a true picture of the UK working population, we ask this question of everyone who is not currently working. We ask people who are retired because the number of people continuing to work after retirement age is increasing. We ask people who are long-term sick or disabled because some intend to go back to work.

guidance.hide_guidance: Why do I need to answer if I am retired or long-term sick or disabled?
